text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This section updates existing procedures for monitoring Authorized IRS e-file Providers per Rev. Proc. 2007–40, Pub 3112, IRS e-file Application and Participation, and Pub 1345, Handbook for Authorized IRS e-file Providers of Individual Income Tax Returns.

Minor editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Third Party Data Store (TPDS) has been change numerous times to Employee User Portal (EUP) because the system is accessed via this EUP. Also, website addresses, legal references, and IRM references were reviewed and updated as necessary. Other significant changes to this IRM include the following:

Section Description Replaced “SSN” with “PTIN” based upon new IRM 4.21.1 requirements for preparers to use PTINs. Clarified to state that an appointment letter should be sent confirming the appointment IRM 4.21.1 for targeted and random visits. Added e-file monitoring report exhibit and instructions. Removed note regarding e-file IRM 4.21.1.2 teams assessing due diligence penalties. Clarified that follow up visits originate from a IRM 4.21.1.10 previous year’s visit. Clarified to state that for targeted visits the Exam HQ e-file analyst will provide to the EMC a list of e-file providers that meet the risk based criteria from which they may IRM 4.21.1.12 select targeted visits. Clarified that the Exam HQ e-file analyst will provide EMCs an inventory of random visits if IRM 4.21.1.13 one is requested. Modified language regarding the possible individuals to be interviewed to include the principal, responsible official, primary contact IRM 4.21.1.15 or alternative contact representative. IRM 4.21.1.16 (2) and Added additional content regarding action (3) taken when conducting visits. Added information regarding whom to make IRM 4.21.1.16 (4) contact with in CI and PSP.

) IRS e-help is responsible for processing and accepting e-file applications all applicants to participate in IRS e-file. In addition, IRS e-help performs ability checks on all applicants and providers to ensure the provider meets requirements to participate in IRS e-file. IRS e-help also monitors the testing a transmitter’s software and documents and the quality of the transmission the e-file returns. They will contact the provider directly to correct problems identified in the transmission of returns. (

) The area office EMC is responsible for all field aspects of monitoring Monitoring is generally accomplished through visits to the provider’s ments either by the EMC and/or e-file Monitor(s) trained by the EMC. The monitor(s) or the EMC monitors the operation of a provider and advises providers of violations identified at the locations. (

) Violation(s) may result in a warning, a written reprimand, suspension or expulsion from participation in IRS e-file, depending on the severity of the in- fraction. Referral and follow-up visits are used to investigate allegations, complaints, and warnings against Authorized IRS e-file Providers. Referrals and follow-ups visits may be mandatory visits depending on the severity of issue and the facts determined. The decision is made by the EMC after reviewing the information. Random and targeted visits are used to determine general compliance within IRS e-file. See IRM

) Participants in IRS e-file are referred to as Authorized IRS e-file Providers (providers). They offer clients a special service which produces higher returns. Benefits include an IRS acknowledgement of receipt of the return. This acknowledgement does not occur with paper returns. Electronic returns also go through validation and are rejected for certain kinds of racies. The accuracy rate of e-file returns is greater than that of paper (
) Applicants select the provider options that are best for them. They may one option, or a combination of the following provider options: (cid:
) Electronic Return Originator (cid:
) Intermediate Service Provider (cid:
) Transmitter (cid:
) Software Developer (cid:
) Online Provider (
) Electronic Return Originator (ERO) - An ERO originates the electronic mission of a tax return through IRS e-file after the taxpayer authorizes the electronic filing of the return. (

) Intermediate Service Provider (ISP) - An ISP receives tax returns from (or from a taxpayer or tax exempt organization that files electronically using personal computer, modem or the Internet, and commercial tax preparation software), processes the return information, and either forwards the to a transmitter, or sends the information back to the ERO (or to the or exempt organization). (

) Transmitter - A transmitter will send the electronic return data directly to the IRS. EROs can become transmitters and transmit return data themselves, or they may contract with accepted third-party transmitters that will transmit the data for them. A transmitter must have software and computers that allow it interface with the IRS. (

) Software Developer - A software developer develops software for the following purposes: a. Formatting electronic return information according to publications issued by the IRS that set forth electronic return file specifications and record layouts for tax returns; and /or b. Transmitting electronic tax return information directly to the IRS.
(08-12-2011) IRS e-file Provider Options
Applicants select the provider options that are best for them. They may one option, or a combination of the following provider options:

a. Formatting electronic return information according to publications by the IRS that set forth electronic return file specifications and record layouts for tax returns; and /or b. Transmitting electronic tax return information directly to the IRS.

) Refund Anticipation Loans/Fees - A refund anticipation loan (RAL) is borrowed by a taxpayer based on the anticipated tax refund. The taxpayer need access to the tax refund quicker than the IRS can release the funds. Since the ERO offers his/her client a RAL based on the federal tax return, taxpayer gains access to the money faster. Note: The Service has no involvement in RALs because a RAL is a contract between the taxpayer and the lender. (cid:
) What is the time frame for a taxpayer to receive a RAL? It depends on bank service of the ERO. If the ERO applied for a RAL and it was approved, the taxpayer can receive funds within
business days from the date the IRS accepts the e-file return. (cid:

) The “Employee User Portal” is the internal IRS portal that allows employees access IRS data and systems, such as TPDS, tax administration processing User Portal systems, financial information systems, and other data and applications, including mission critical applications. Registration and authentication are required for access to sensitive and mission critical applications and all user interactions with those systems are encrypted from workstation to portal the IRS internal network. The EUP also allows IRS employee users with LAN accounts (Windows Network Login) to access intranet sites, selected applica- tions, non-sensitive data, and selected sensitive processing where network encryption and modernization logon are not required (e.g., employees access to selected elements of their own personnel data). IRS network authentication is required for access to any secure materials or services, and is required in order to access registration and authentication. IRS employees access IRS applications through a portal accessible only from the IRS Intranet. The EUP authenticates internal IRS users and provides role-based access control to modernized applications. All web sites dealing with sensitive tax, identifica- tion, or financial data will be accessed via the EUP. At this time, modernized applications using the EUP for access include e-Services, Modernized e-file and Integrated Financial System (IFS). The database will be updated weekly throughout the year. Access to the website requires completion of an Online
, Automated Information System (AIS) User Registration/Change (

PIN /IRS e-file Signature Authorization (Form 8879)

[HISTORY: Beginning with the 2008 filing season, tax practitioners can e-file individual income tax returnsonly if the returns are signed electronically using one of two methods: either a Self-Select PersonalIdentification Number (PIN) or a Practitioner PIN. A Self-Select PIN allows taxpayers to electronically signtheir e-filed return by selecting a five-digit PIN. A Practitioner PIN is used when a taxpayer authorizes anElectronic Return Originator (ERO) to input an electronic signature on behalf of the taxpayer. PractitionerPINs require the use of Form 8879, IRS e-file Signature Authorization, which is retained by the ERO.

Tax practitioners no longer submit a paper signature for e-filed returns by using Form 8453, U.S. IndividualIncome Tax Declaration for an IRS e-file Return. Instead, a newly designed Form 8453 is used to transmitsupporting paper documents that are required to be submitted to the IRS with e-filed returns.]
